00059 #define MATRIX_USE_EXCEPTION_HANDLING
00060 #ifdef MATRIX_USE_EXCEPTION_HANDLING
00061 
00062   /**
00063   * \class   MatrixException
00064   * \brief   A class for exceptions thrown by the Matrix class.
00065   * 
00066   * The MATRIX_USE_EXCEPTION_HANDLING define enables the use of exception 
00067   * handling using try{} catch{}. A MatrixException is thrown. The use of 
00068   * exception handling is very highly recommended. When it is turned off, 
00069   * the matrix will try to output a message and then call 'exit(1)'.
00070   *
00071   * \code
00072   * int main()
00073   * { 
00074   *   try
00075   *   {
00076   *     Matrix A(2,2);
00077   *     double d = A(3,1).real(); // causes an out of bounds exception
00078   *   }
00079   *   catch( MatrixException& matrix_exception )
00080   *   {
00081   *     cout << matrix_exception << endl;
00082   *   }
00083   *   catch ( ... )
00084   *   {
00085   *     cout << "Caught unknown exception" << endl;
00086   *   }
00087   *   return 0;
00088   * }
00089   * \endcode
00090   */
00091   class MatrixException
00092   {  
00093   public: 
00094     /// \brief  The constructor.
00095     MatrixException( const char* msg );
00096 
00097     /// \brief  The copy constructor.
00098     MatrixException(const MatrixException& matrix_exception);
00099 
00100     /// \brief  The destuctor.
00101     virtual ~MatrixException() { /* nothing needed yet */ };
00102 
00103     /// \brief  Return a copy of the exception message.
00104     std::string GetExceptionMessage();
00105 
00106     /// \brief  Overload the casting operator to a string.
00107     operator const char*();
00108 
00109   public:
00110     /// The matrix exception string.  
00111     std::string m_ExceptionString;
00112 
00113   private:
00114     /// The matrix exception character string.  
00115     char m_msg[256];    
00116   };
00117 
00118 #endif

00121   /**
00122   * \class   Matrix
00123   * \brief   The two dimensional matrix class. 
00124   *          Both real and complex data are inherently supported.
00125   * 
00126   * The matrix class supports advanced real and complex functionality. It is
00127   * optimized for columnwise operations.
00128   *
00129   * Refer to example_main.cpp for a complete example program using the Matrix.
00130   */
00131   class Matrix
00132   {  
00133   public: // Constructors / Destructor
00134 
00135     /// \brief  This function enables or disables a global flag
00136     ///         that forces single element matrices to be treated
00137     ///         as scalars. This is enabled by default. 
00138     static void Treat1x1MatricesAsScalar( bool enable = true );
00139 
00140     /// \brief  The default constructor (no data allocated yet).
00141     Matrix();                                             
00142 
00143     /// \brief  A vector style constructor.
00144     ///
00145     /// Matrix A(nrows);  creates an nrowsx1 real 'vector'.
00146     /// A complex vector must be created using Matrix A(nrows,ncols,false);
00147     Matrix(const unsigned nrows);
00148 
00149     /// \brief  A matrix style constructor.
00150     ///
00151     /// Matrix A(nrows,ncols); creates an nrowsxncols real 'matrix'. A real matrix is assumed.
00152     /// Matrix A(nrows,ncols,false); creates an nrowsxncols complex 'matrix'. A real matrix is assumed.
00153     Matrix(const unsigned nrows, const unsigned ncols, const bool isReal=true);
00154 
00155     /// \brief  The copy constructor.
00156     Matrix(const Matrix& mat);                          
00157 
00158     /// \brief  A constructor reading data from a file.
00159     Matrix(const char* path, bool& itWorked);
00160 
00161     /// \brief  The constructor as a copy from a static matrix.
00162     Matrix(const double mat[], const unsigned nrows, const unsigned ncols=1 ); 
00163 
00164     /// \brief  The destructor.
00165     virtual ~Matrix();
00166 
00167     /// \brief  The assignment operator from another matrix.
00168     ///
00169     /// e.g. Matrix B; Matrix A; B = "[1 2 3; 4 5 6]"; A = B; // A == [1 2 3; 4 5 6], A is (2x3)
00170     Matrix& operator=(const Matrix& mat);
00171 
00172     /// \brief  The assignment operator from a scalar double value.
00173     ///
00174     /// e.g. Matrix A; A = 2.0; // A is (1x1).
00175     Matrix& operator=(const double value);
00176 
00177     
00178     /// \brief  The assignment operator from a std::complex<double> value.
00179     ///
00180     /// e.g. Matrix A; A = 2.0; // A is (1x1).
00181     Matrix& operator=(const std::complex<double> value);
00182 
00183     /// \brief  The assignement operator from a string matrix.
00184     ///
00185     /// There are two general possible interpretations of the string input.
00186     ///
00187     /// (1) Square bracket delimited matrix. \n
00188     /// Matrix A; A = "[1 2 3; 4 5 6]" or A = "[1, 2, 3; 4, 5, 6]" \n
00189     /// In this case '[' donates the start of a matrix and ']' denotes the end. \n
00190     /// Row vectors [1 2 3] and [4 5 6] are separated by ';'.  \n
00191     /// Commas can delimit row vector data but are not needed. \n
00192     /// Complex input: e.g. A = "[1+1i 2+3j 1-2i; 4 5 6]" or A = "[1+1i, 2+3j, 1-2i; 4, 5, 6]" \n
00193     ///
00194     /// (2) Free form delimited matrix. \n
00195     /// Matrix A; A = "1 2 3 \n 4 5 6 \n" \n
00196     /// In this case, the newline delimits different rows of the matrix. (\\r\\n also works). \n
00197     /// Row vectors can still be delimited by ';' as well. \n
00198     /// B = "1 2 3; 4 5 6;\n 7 8 9" will set a 3x3 matrix == [1 2 3; 4 5 6; 7 8 9]. \n
00199     /// Commas can delimit row vector data but are not needed. \n
00200     /// Complex input: e.g. A = "[1+1i 2+3j 1-2i\n 4 5 6]" or  \n
00201     ///                     A = "1+1i, 2+3j, 1-2i\n 4, 5, 6" or  \n
00202     ///                     A = "1+1i 2+3j 1-2i; 4, 5, 6". \n
00203     /// All result in A = [1+1i 2+3i 1-2i; 4 5 6]; \n
00204     Matrix& operator=(const char* strMatrix); //!< The assignment operator from a matrix string. 
00205 
00206   public:
00207 
00208     /// \brief  Clear the matrix memory. Set the matrix to size 0x0.
00209     bool Clear();
00210 
00211   public: // Matrix Qualifiers
00212 
00213     /// \brief  Is this matrix empty();
00214     bool isEmpty() const;
00215 
00216     /// \brief  Is the matrix mat conformal for multiplication (*this * mat)?
00217     bool isConformal(const Matrix& mat) const;
00218 
00219     /// \brief  Is this matrix the same size as mat?
00220     bool isSameSize(const Matrix& mat) const;  
00221 
00222     /// \brief  Is this a square matrix?
00223     bool isSquare() const;
00224 
00225     /// Check if this a real matrix.
00226     bool isReal() const;
00227 
00228     /// Check if this a complex matrix.
00229     bool isComplex() const; 
00230 
00231     unsigned GetNrCols() const;   //!< return no. of cols
00232     unsigned ncols() const;       //!< return no. of cols
00233     unsigned GetNrElems() const;  //!< return total no. of elements
00234     unsigned nelems() const;      //!< return total no. of elements
00235     unsigned GetNrRows() const;   //!< return no. of rows         
00236     unsigned nrows() const;       //!< return no. of rows         
00237 
00238 
00239     /// \brief  Return the real part of the matrix at this row and column.
00240     double real(const unsigned row, const unsigned col);
00241 
00242     /// \brief  Return the real part of the matrix at this vector index.
00243     double real(const unsigned index);
00244 
00245     /// \brief  Return the imaginary part of the matrix at this row and column.
00246     double imag(const unsigned row, const unsigned col);
00247 
00248     /// \brief  Return the imaginary part of the matrix at this vector index.
00249     double imag(const unsigned index);

00252   public: // Input Operations
00253 
00254     /// \brief  Read the marix from an ASCII file with the path given by the 'c' style string
00255     /// (with support for many delimiters, whitespace, or ',', or ';', or many others) 
00256     /// or a compressed BINARY matrix file used in the Save function.
00257     /// Complex and real data input are supported.
00258     ///
00259     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise
00260     bool ReadFromFile( const char *path );
00261     
00262     /// \brief  Read the marix from an ASCII file with the path given by the std::string
00263     /// (with support for many delimiters, whitespace, or ',', or ';', or many others) 
00264     /// or a compressed BINARY matrix file used in the Save function.
00265     /// Complex and real data input are supported.
00266     ///
00267     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise    
00268     bool ReadFromFile( std::string path )
00269     {
00270       return ReadFromFile( path.c_str() );
00271     }
00272 
00273 
00274     /**  
00275     * \brief  A safe function for performing a copy of another matrix.
00276     *
00277     * \code
00278     * Matrix A(2,2);
00279     * A[0][0] = 1.0;
00280     * A[0][1] = 2.0;
00281     * A[1][0] = 3.0;
00282     * A[1][1] = 4.0;
00283     * Matrix B;
00284     * if( !B.Copy(A) )
00285     *   return false;
00286     * \endcode
00287     *
00288     * \return true if successful, false otherwise
00289     */
00290     bool Copy( Matrix& src );
00291 
00292 
00293     /**      
00294     * \brief  A safe function for setting the matrix from a double.
00295     *
00296     * \code
00297     * double d = 10.0;
00298     * Matrix A;
00299     * if( !A.Copy(d) )
00300     *   return false;
00301     * \endcode
00302     *
00303     * \return true if successful, false otherwise
00304     */
00305     bool Copy( const double& value );
00306 
00307 
00308     /**      
00309     * \brief  A safe function for setting the matrix from a std::complex<double>.
00310     *
00311     * \code
00312     * std::complex<double> cplx(1.0,2.0);
00313     * Matrix A;
00314     * if( !A.Copy(cplx) )
00315     *   return false;
00316     * \endcode
00317     *
00318     * \return true if successful, false otherwise
00319     */
00320     bool Copy( const std::complex<double>& cplx );

00325     /// \brief  Saves a matrix to the specified file path (a 'c' style string)
00326     /// using a proprietary compressed format.
00327     /// ADVANCED EDITION ONLY. BASIC EDITION will return false.
00328     ///
00329     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise
00330     bool Save( const char* path );
00331 
00332     /// \brief  Saves a matrix to the specified file path (a std::string)
00333     /// using a proprietary compressed format.
00334     /// ADVANCED EDITION ONLY. BASIC EDITION will return false.
00335     ///
00336     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise
00337     bool Save( std::string path )
00338     {
00339       return Save( path.c_str() );
00340     }
00341 
00342     /// \brief  Print the matrix to a file with automatically determined column width 
00343     /// and the specified precision, uses "%'blank''-'autowidth.precision'g'", to 
00344     /// the 'c' style path string provided.
00345     ///
00346     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise
00347     bool Print( const char *path, const unsigned precision, bool append = false );
00348 
00349     /// \brief  Print the matrix to a file with automatically determined column width 
00350     /// and the specified precision, uses "%'blank''-'autowidth.precision'g'", to 
00351     /// the std:string path provided.
00352     ///
00353     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise
00354     bool Print( std::string path, const unsigned precision, bool append = false ) 
00355     {
00356       return Print( path.c_str(), precision );
00357     }
00358 
00359     /**
00360     * \brief  Print the matrix to the standard output (stdout) with automatically 
00361     * determined column width and the specified precision, 
00362     * uses "%'blank''-'autowidth.precision'g'".
00363     *
00364     *  e.g. \n
00365     *  \code
00366     *  Matrix A;
00367     *  A = "[1.123 0 2.123 -1; 3.123 0 4.123 -1]";  // Set A using string notation.
00368     *  bool result = A.PrintStdout(6); // Print to stdout with automatic width determination.
00369     *  // 0123456789012345678901234567890
00370     *  // results in:
00371     *  // 0123456789012345678901234567890
00372     *  //  1.123  0  2.123 -1
00373     *  //  3.123  0  4.123 -1
00374     *  \endcode
00375     *    
00376     * \return true if successful, false otherwise
00377     */
00378     bool PrintStdout( const unsigned precision );
00379 
00380     /**
00381     *  \brief  Print the matrix to a buffer of maxlength with automatically determined column width 
00382     *  and the specified precision, uses "%'blank''-'autowidth.precision'g'"
00383     *
00384     *  e.g. \n
00385     *  \code
00386     *  Matrix A;
00387     *  A = "[1.123 0 2.123 -1; 3.123 0 4.123 -1]";  // Set A using string notation.
00388     *  char buffer[256]; 
00389     *  bool result = A.PrintToBuffer( buffer, 256, 6); // Print to a buffer with automatic width determination.
00390     *  cout << buffer << endl;
00391     *  // 0123456789012345678901234567890
00392     *  // results in:
00393     *  // 0123456789012345678901234567890
00394     *  //  1.123  0  2.123 -1
00395     *  //  3.123  0  4.123 -1
00396     *  \endcode
00397     *    
00398     *  \return true if successful, false otherwise
00399     */
00400     bool PrintToBuffer( char* buffer, const unsigned maxlength, const unsigned precision );
00401 
00402

00406     ///
00407     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise
00408     bool PrintFixedWidth( const char* path, const unsigned width, const unsigned precision, bool append = false );
00409

00421     /**
00422     *  \brief  Print the matrix to a buffer of maxlength with specifed width and precision
00423     *  PrintAutoWidth is recommended over this function, "%'blank''-'width.precision'g'"
00424     *
00425     *  e.g. \n
00426     *  \code
00427     *  Matrix A;
00428     *  A = "[1.123 2.123 -1; 3.123 4.123 -1]";  // Set A using string notation.
00429     *  char buffer[256]; 
00430     *  bool result = A.PrintFixedWidthToBuffer( buffer, 256, 10, 6 ); // Print to a buffer with fixed width.
00431     *  cout << buffer << endl;
00432     *  // 0123456789012345678901234567890
00433     *  // results in:
00434     *  //  1.123     2.123    -1
00435     *  //  3.123     4.123    -1
00436     *  \endcode
00437     *    
00438     *  \return true if successful, false otherwise
00439     */
00440     bool PrintFixedWidthToBuffer( char* buffer, const unsigned maxlength, const unsigned width, const unsigned precision );
00441

00457     /**
00458     *  \brief  Print the matrix to a 'c' style string buffer of maxlength with specifed precision and delimiter.
00459     *
00460     *  e.g. \n
00461     *  \code
00462     *  Matrix A;
00463     *  A = "[1.123 2.123; 3.123 4.123]";  // Set A using string notation.
00464     *  char buffer[256]; 
00465     *  bool result = A.PrintDelimitedToBuffer( buffer, 256, 6, ',' ); // Print to a buffer using comma delimiters.
00466     *  cout << buffer << endl;
00467     *  // results in:
00468     *  // 1.123,2.123
00469     *  // 3.123,4.123
00470     *  \endcode
00471     *    
00472     *  \return true if successful, false otherwise
00473     */
00474     bool PrintDelimitedToBuffer( char *buffer, const unsigned maxlength, const unsigned precision, const char delimiter );
00475 
00476     /**
00477     *  \brief  Print a row to a 'c' style string buffer.
00478     *  
00479     *  e.g. \n
00480     *  \code
00481     *  Matrix A;
00482     *  A = "[1.123 2.123; 3.123 4.123]";  // Set A using string notation.
00483     *  char buffer[256]; 
00484     *  bool result = A.PrintRowToString( 1, buffer, 256, 4, 6 ); // Print the second row to the char buffer.
00485     *  cout << buffer << endl;
00486     *  // results in:
00487     *  // 3.123   4.123
00488     *  \endcode
00489     * 
00490     *  \return true if successful, false otherwise
00491     */
00492     bool PrintRowToString( const unsigned row, char *buffer, const unsigned maxlength, const int width, const int precision );

00507     /** \brief  Remove the rows and columns specified by the indices in the rows[] and cols[] arrays.
00508     *
00509     * \code
00510     * Matrix A(4,4);
00511     * unsigned rows[2];
00512     * unsigned cols[2];
00513     * rows[0] = 0; // remove row 0
00514     * rows[1] = 2; // remove row 2
00515     * cols[0] = 0; // remove column 0
00516     * cols[1] = 2; // romve column 2
00517     * A.RemoveRowsAndColumns( 2, (unsigned int *)rows, 2, (unsigned int *)cols );
00518     * // A is now a 2x2 matrix
00519     * \endcode
00520     *
00521     * \return true if successful, false otherwise.  
00522     */
00523     bool RemoveRowsAndColumns( const unsigned nrows, const unsigned rows[], const unsigned ncols, const unsigned cols[] );
00524

00554   public: // Setting matrix values
00555 
00556     /// \brief  Set the matrix from the static 'c' style matrix indexed by mat[i*ncols + j].
00557     ///
00558     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.    
00559     bool SetFromStaticMatrix( const double mat[], const unsigned nrows, const unsigned ncols );
00560 
00561     /**
00562     * \brief  Setting the matrix values from a string matrix.
00563     *
00564     * There are two general possible interpretations of the string input.
00565     *
00566     * (1) Square bracket delimited matrix. \n
00567     * \code
00568     * bool result;
00569     * Matrix A;
00570     * result = A.SetFromMatrixString("[1 2 3; 4 5 6]");
00571     * // equivalently 
00572     * result = A.SetFromMatrixString("[1, 2, 3; 4, 5, 6]");
00573     * \endcode
00574     * In this case '[' donates the start of a matrix and ']' denotes the end. \n
00575     * Row vectors [1 2 3] and [4 5 6] are separated by ';'.  \n
00576     * Commas can delimit row vector data but are not needed. \n
00577     * Complex input: \n
00578     * \code 
00579     * bool result;
00580     * Matrix A;
00581     * result = A.SetFromMatrixString("[1+1i 2+3j 1-2i; 4 5 6]");
00582     * \endcode
00583     *
00584     * (2) Free form delimited matrix. \n
00585     * \code
00586     * bool result;
00587     * Matrix A; 
00588     * result = A.SetFromMatrixString("1 2 3 \n 4 5 6 \n");
00589     * \endcode
00590     * In this case, the newline delimits different rows of the matrix. (\\r\\n also works). \n
00591     * Row vectors can still be delimited by ';' as well. \n
00592     * \code
00593     * bool result;
00594     * Matrix B;
00595     * B.SetFromMatrixString("1 2 3; 4 5 6;\n 7 8 9"); // will set a 3x3 matrix == [1 2 3; 4 5 6; 7 8 9].
00596     * \endcode
00597     * Commas can delimit row vector data but are not needed. \n
00598     * Complex input: \n
00599     * \code
00600     * A.SetFromMatrixString("[1+1i 2+3j 1-2i\n 4 5 6]"); // or
00601     * A.SetFromMatrixString("1+1i, 2+3j, 1-2i\n 4, 5, 6"); // or
00602     * A.SetFromMatrixString("1+1i 2+3j 1-2i; 4, 5, 6"); 
00603     * \endcode
00604     * All result in \n
00605     * A = [1+1i 2+3i 1-2i; 4 5 6]; \n
00606     *
00607     * \return true if successful, false otherwise.
00608     */
00609     bool SetFromMatrixString(const char* strMatrix);
00610 
00611 
00612     /// \breif  Copy the src data in column col to dst matrix, resize dst if possible & necessary.
00613     ///
00614     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.    
00615     bool CopyColumn( const unsigned src_col, Matrix &dst );
00616 
00617     /// \brief  Insert a submatrix (src) into dst, starting at indices dst(row,col).
00618     ///
00619     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.    
00620     bool InsertSubMatrix( const Matrix &src, const unsigned dst_row, const unsigned dst_col );
00621

00624     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.  
00625     bool Zero();
00626

00639     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.    
00640     bool Fill( const double value );

00681     /// \brief  Round the matrix elements to the specified presision. \n
00682     /// e.g. precision = 0    1.8    -> 2     \n

00685     /// e.g. precision = 3,   1.4566 -> 1.457 \n
00686     ///
00687     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.    
00688     bool Inplace_Round( const unsigned precision );

00820     /// \brief  Sorts each column of the matrix in ascending order.
00821     /// If complex, sorts based on magnitude.
00822     ///
00823     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
00824     bool Inplace_SortAscending();
00825

00827     /// If complex, sorts based on magnitude.
00828     ///
00829     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.

00831

00834     ///
00835     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.

00837

00840     ///
00841     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.

00843 
00844     /// \brief  Sorts a specific column in ascending order and fills a MTX 
00845     /// column vector with the sorted index. The index vector will be resized 
00846     /// if index->nrows != M->nrows. If complex, sorts based on magnitude.
00847     ///
00848     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
00849     bool Inplace_SortColumnIndexed( const unsigned col, Matrix &Index );
00850 
00851     /// \brief  Sorts the entire matrix by a specific column.
00852     /// If complex, sorts based on magnitude.
00853     ///
00854     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
00855     bool Inplace_SortByColumn( const unsigned col );
00856 
00857     /// \brief  Computes the inplace inverse of the matrix.
00858     ///
00859     /// Uses fast closed form solutions for:
00860     /// 1x1, 2x2, 3x3
00861     ///
00862     /// Otherwise, the matrix is first tested to determine if it is a symmetric 
00863     /// positive-definite matrix. If so, Cholesky decomposition is used
00864     /// to facilitate the inversion of a lower triangular matrix. If the
00865     /// matrix is not symmetric and positive-definite robust inversion
00866     /// using gaussing elimination is attempted.
00867     /// 
00868     /// If the matrix is singular, the original matrix is unchanged.
00869     ///
00870     /// \return true if successful, false if empty, singular or not square.
00871     bool Inplace_Invert();
00872 
00873     /// \brief  Perfroms an inplace inverse using Gaussian Elimination methods.
00874     ///
00875     /// \return true if successful, false if empty, singular or not square.
00876     bool Inplace_InvertRobust();
00877 
00878     /// \brief  Compute the inplace inverse of a unit lower triangular matrix. 
00879     /// An example unit lower triangular matrix is: \n
00880     ///      A = [     1    0    0;          \n
00881     ///               -2    2    0;          \n
00882     ///                4   -3    3 ]; with   \n
00883     /// inv(A) = [     1    0    0;          \n
00884     ///                1  1/2    0;          \n
00885     ///             -1/3  1/2  1/3 ];        \n
00886     ///
00887     /// \return true if successful, false if empty, singular or not square.
00888     bool Inplace_LowerTriangularInverse();
00889 
00890     /// \brief  Compute the inplace Fourier Transform of each column of the matrix.
00891     /// \return   true if successful, false if unable to perform the FFT.
00892     bool Inplace_FFT();
00893 
00894     /// \brief  Compute the inplace inverse Fourier Transform of each column of the matrix.
00895     /// \return   true if successful, false if unable to perform the FFT.
00896     bool Inplace_IFFT();
00897

00902     /// e.g. Matrix A; A.Add(B,C);
00903     ///
00904     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
00905     bool Add( const Matrix &B, const Matrix &C );
00906

00931     /// e.g. b = 2:-2:-9 = [2; 0; -2; -4; -6; -9;] \n

00933     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.

01140     /// \brief  Computes the norm of the specified column.
01141     /// If real, norm = sqrt( sum( val*val ) ).
01142     /// If complex, norm = sqrt( sum( val*conjugate(val) ) ).
01143     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
01144     bool GetStats_ColumnNorm( const unsigned col, double &value );
01145 
01146     /// \brief  Computes the norm of the specified row.
01147     /// If real, norm = sqrt( sum( val*val ) ).
01148     /// If complex, norm = sqrt( sum( val*conjugate(val) ) ).
01149     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
01150     bool GetStats_RowNorm( const unsigned row, double &value );
01151 
01152     /// \brief  Computes the norm of the matrix.
01153     /// If real, norm = sqrt( sum( val*val ) ).
01154     /// If complex, norm = sqrt( sum( val*conjugate(val) ) ).
01155     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
01156     bool GetStats_Norm( double &value );
01157 
01158     /// \brief  Computes the sample RMS value for the specified column.
01159     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
01160     bool GetStats_ColumnRMS( const unsigned col, double &value );
01161 
01162     /// \brief  Computes the sample RMS value for the specified row.
01163     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
01164     bool GetStats_RowRMS( const unsigned row, double &value );
01165 
01166     /// \brief  Computes the sample RMS value for the matrix.
01167     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
01168     bool GetStats_RMS( double &value );
01169 
01170 
01171     /// \brief  Computes the sample skewness value for the specified column.
01172     /// The skewness is the third central moment divided by the cube of the standard deviation.
01173     /// If the matrix is real, only the real value, re is set, im = 0. 
01174     /// If the matrix is complex, both re and im are set.
01175     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
01176     bool GetStats_ColumnSkewness( const unsigned col, double &re, double &im );
01177 
01178     /// \brief  Computes the sample skewness value for the specified row.
01179     /// The skewness is the third central moment divided by the cube of the standard deviation.
01180     /// If the matrix is real, only the real value, re is set, im = 0. 
01181     /// If the matrix is complex, both re and im are set.
01182     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
01183     bool GetStats_RowSkewness( const unsigned row, double &re, double &im );
01184 
01185     /// \brief  Computes the sample skewness value for the matrix.
01186     /// The skewness is the third central moment divided by the cube of the standard deviation.
01187     /// If the matrix is real, only the real value, re is set, im = 0. 
01188     /// If the matrix is complex, both re and im are set.
01189     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
01190     bool GetStats_Skewness( double &re, double &im );
01191 
01192 
01193 
01194     /// \brief  Computes the sample kurtosis value for the specified column.
01195     /// The kurtosis is the fourth central moment divided by fourth power of the standard deviation.
01196     /// If the matrix is real, only the real value, re is set, im = 0. 
01197     /// If the matrix is complex, both re and im are set.
01198     /// To adjust the computed kurtosis value for bias, subtract 3 from the real component.
01199     /// Reference: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurtosis.
01200     /// Reference: http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Kurtosis.html (kurtosis proper is computed).
01201     /// g_2 = \frac{m_4}{m_{2}^2} = \frac{n\,\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \overline{x})^4}{\left(\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \overline{x})^2\right)^2}
01202     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
01203     bool GetStats_ColumnKurtosis( const unsigned col, double &re, double &im );
01204 
01205     /// \brief  Computes the sample kurtosis value for the specified row.
01206     /// The kurtosis is the fourth central moment divided by fourth power of the standard deviation.
01207     /// If the matrix is real, only the real value, re is set, im = 0. 
01208     /// If the matrix is complex, both re and im are set.
01209     /// To adjust the computed kurtosis value for bias, subtract 3 from the real component.
01210     /// Reference: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurtosis.
01211     /// Reference: http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Kurtosis.html (kurtosis proper is computed).
01212     /// g_2 = \frac{m_4}{m_{2}^2} = \frac{n\,\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \overline{x})^4}{\left(\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \overline{x})^2\right)^2}
01213     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
01214     bool GetStats_RowKurtosis( const unsigned row, double &re, double &im );
01215 
01216     /// \brief  Computes the sample kurtosis value for the matrix.
01217     /// The kurtosis is the fourth central moment divided by fourth power of the standard deviation.
01218     /// If the matrix is real, only the real value, re is set, im = 0. 
01219     /// If the matrix is complex, both re and im are set.
01220     /// To adjust the computed kurtosis value for bias, subtract 3 from the real component.
01221     /// Reference: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurtosis.
01222     /// Reference: http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Kurtosis.html (kurtosis proper is computed).
01223     /// g_2 = \frac{m_4}{m_{2}^2} = \frac{n\,\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \overline{x})^4}{\left(\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \overline{x})^2\right)^2}
01224     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
01225     bool GetStats_Kurtosis( double &re, double &im );
01226

01262     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.

01267     /// an upper triangular matrix, U, and permutation matrix P so that
01268     /// P*X = L*U.
01269     /// P, L and U are copmuted correctly if IsFullRank is set to true.
01270     /// e.g. Matrix A; A = ...; bool isFullRank, Matrix L,U,P; bool result = A.GetLUFactorization( isFullRank, P, L, U );
01271     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.

01300     /// \brief  Retrieve the matrix comment string. The string
01301     /// will be empty if none is available. The matrix comment string
01302     /// is often the header line read when using ReadFromFile(). \n
01303     /// e.g. file.txt has:
01304     /// time(s)   x(m)   y(m)
01305     /// 1.0       20.0   30.0
01306     ///
01307     /// \code
01308     /// bool result;
01309     /// Matrix A;
01310     /// result = A.ReadFromFile("file.txt");
01311     /// // A == [1.0 20.0 30.0]
01312     /// std::string comment = A.GetMatrixComment();
01313     /// // comment == "time(s)   x(m)   y(m)"
01314     /// \endcode
01315     ///
01316     /// \return The matrix comment string.
01317     std::string GetMatrixComment();
01318 
01319 
01320     /// \brief  Alter the matrix so that its data is within the startTime to the startTime+duration
01321     /// and compensate for any rollovers in the time system (e.g. GPS time in seconds rolls over
01322     /// at 604800.0 s). This function assumes that time is one of the matrix columns and requires
01323     /// this index, the timeColumn.
01324     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
01325     bool TimeWindow( 
01326       const unsigned timeColumn, //!< The column containing time.
01327       const double startTime,    //!< The specified start time (inclusive).
01328       const double duration,     //!< The duration to include.
01329       const double rolloverTime  //!< The potential time at which system time rolls over.
01330       );
01331 
01332     /// \brief  Alter the matrix so that its data is within [startTime endTime].
01333     /// This function assumes that time is one of the matrix columns and requires
01334     /// this index, the timeColumn.
01335     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
01336     bool TimeLimit( 
01337       const unsigned timeColumn, //!< The column containing time
01338       const double startTime,    //!< The specified start time (inclusive)
01339       const double endTime       //!< The duration to include
01340       );
01341 
01342     /// \brief  This static function matches matrices in time with specified precision
01343     /// where time is a column of each matrix. This function also
01344     /// allows time to rollover at a specified interval.
01345     ///
01346     ///    precision 0 = match to whole number \n
01347     ///    precision 1 = match to nearest 0.1 \n
01348     ///    precision 2 = match to nearest 0.01 \n
01349     ///    etc. \n
01350     /// rolloverTime examples \n
01351     ///     GPS time of week (s): rolloverTime= 604800.0 \n
01352     ///     hours               : rolloverTime = 24.0 \n
01353     ///     minutes             : rolloverTime = 60.0 \n
01354     ///
01355     /// The time data must be non-decreasing but the time may rollover
01356     /// by the specified amount. 
01357     /// e.g. rolloverTime = 60.0 \n
01358     ///      0,1,2,3,4,...59,60,1,2,5,10,60,1,2,3... \n
01359     ///
01360     /// This function may be called by: bool result = Matrix::TimeMatch( ... );
01361     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
01362     static bool TimeMatch( 
01363       Matrix &A,                   //!< The matrix with interpolation times
01364       const unsigned timeColumnA,  //!< The zero based column index for matrix A
01365       Matrix &B,                   //!< The matrix to be interpolated
01366       const unsigned timeColumnB,  //!< The zero based column index for matrix B
01367       const unsigned precision,    //!< The rounding precision used for time matching, 0 = whole, 1 = 0.1, 2 = 0.01, etc
01368       const double rolloverTime    //!< The rollover time, e.g. 60 s for minute based timing, 0.0 means rollovers not allowed
01369       );
01370 
01371     /// \brief  This static function interpolates Matrix B values by the times defined 
01372     /// in the column in Matrix A. Time must be increasing but times can 
01373     /// rollover with the specified rolloverTime.
01374     ///
01375     /// This function returns A and B with the same number of rows and 
01376     /// time aligned time columns.
01377     ///
01378     /// This function may be called by: bool result = Matrix::Interpolate( ... );
01379     /// \return true if successful, false otherwise.
01380     ///  
01381     static bool Interpolate( 
01382       Matrix &A,                    //!< The matrix with interpolation times
01383       const unsigned timeColumnA,   //!< The zero based column index for matrix A
01384       Matrix &B,                    //!< The matrix to be interpolated
01385       const unsigned timeColumnB,   //!< The zero based column index for matrix B
01386       const double maxInterpolationInterval, //!< The largest interpolation interval allowed
01387       const double rolloverTime     //!< The rollover time, e.g. 60 s for minute based timing, 0.0 means rollovers not allowed
01388       );
01389 
01390

01394     Matrix  Column(const unsigned col);
01395 
01396     /// \brief  Return the row matrix specified by the column index. Returns (ncols x 1).
01397     Matrix  Row(const unsigned row);
01398

01406     Matrix  Diagonal();

01419     /// Power of two uses IFFT, otherwise fast IDFT.

01425     /// \brief  This is a nested class that is an element of the matrix. i.e. Matrix M; M(i,j) is the element. 
01426     /// It is used for operator(,) access by the Matrix.
01427     class Element
01428     {
01429     public:
01430 
01431       /// \brief  The only constructor binds the reference to the deep level matrix.
01432       /// The row and column members are set later.
01433       Element(MTX& mtx);
01434 
01435       /// \brief  The destructor.
01436       virtual ~Element();
01437 
01438     private:
01439       friend class Matrix; //!< The matrix class is a friend.
01440 
01441       MTX& m_mtx;     //!< The reference to the deep level matrix.
01442       unsigned m_row; //!< The corresponding row of this element in the matrix.
01443       unsigned m_col; //!< The corresponding column of this element in the matrix.
01444 
01445     public:
01446 
01447       const double real(); //!< Get the real part.
01448       const double imag(); //!< Get the imaginary part.
01449       
01450       /// \brief  The operator overload for setting the matrix element from a double.
01451       const Element& operator= (double v);
01452 
01453       /// \brief  The operator overload for setting the matrix element from a std::complex.
01454       const Element& operator= (std::complex<double> v);
01455 
01456       /// \brief  The operator overload for setting the matrix element from another the matrix element.
01457       const Element& operator= (Element v);
01458 
01459       /// \brief  This operator allows explict conversion to a std::complex.
01460       operator const std::complex<double>() const;
01461 
01462       void operator+= (const double scalar);            //!< \brief  Add a scalar inplace. 
01463       void operator+= (const std::complex<double>& v);  //!< \brief  Add a complex value inplace. 
01464       void operator+= (const Element& v);               //!< \brief  Add a Element inplace. 
01465       void operator-= (const double scalar);            //!< \brief  Subtract a scalar inplace. 
01466       void operator-= (const std::complex<double>& v);  //!< \brief  Subtract a complex value inplace. 
01467       void operator-= (const Element& v);               //!< \brief  Subtract a Element inplace. 
01468       void operator*= (const double scalar);            //!< \brief  Multiply a scalar inplace. 
01469       void operator*= (const std::complex<double>& v);  //!< \brief  Multiply a complex value inplace. 
01470       void operator*= (const Element& v);               //!< \brief  Multiply a Element inplace. 
01471       void operator/= (const double scalar);            //!< \brief  Divide a scalar inplace. 
01472       void operator/= (const std::complex<double>& v);  //!< \brief  Divide a complex value inplace. 
01473       void operator/= (const Element& v);               //!< \brief  Divide a Element inplace. 
01474       
01475       /// \brief  The operator overload for adding a double to an element.
01476       friend const std::complex<double> operator+ (const Element& m, double scalar);
01477 
01478       /// \brief  The operator overload for adding an element to an element.
01479       friend const std::complex<double> operator+ (const Element& a, const Element& b);
01480 
01481       /// \brief  The operator overload for adding an element to an complex.
01482       friend const std::complex<double> operator+ (const Element& a, const std::complex<double>& b);
01483 
01484       /// \brief  The operator overload for adding an element and a double.
01485       friend const std::complex<double> operator+ (double scalar, const Element& m);
01486 
01487       /// \brief  The operator overload for adding a complex and an element
01488       friend const std::complex<double> operator+ (const std::complex<double>& b, const Element& a);
01489 
01490 
01491       /// \brief  The operator overload for subtracting a double from an element.
01492       friend const std::complex<double> operator- (const Element& m, double scalar);
01493       
01494       /// \brief  The operator overload for subtracting an element from an element.
01495       friend const std::complex<double> operator- (const Element& a, const Element& b);
01496 
01497       /// \brief  The operator overload for subtracting an complex from an element.
01498       friend const std::complex<double> operator- (const Element& a, const std::complex<double>& b);
01499 
01500       /// \brief  The operator overload for subtracting an element from a double.
01501       friend const std::complex<double> operator- (double scalar, const Element& m);
01502 
01503       /// \brief  The operator overload for subtracting an element from a complex.
01504       friend const std::complex<double> operator- (const std::complex<double>& b, const Element& a);
01505 
01506 
01507       /// \brief  The operator overload for multiplying an element and a double.
01508       friend const std::complex<double> operator* (const Element& m, double scalar);
01509       
01510       /// \brief  The operator overload for multiplying an element and an element.
01511       friend const std::complex<double> operator* (const Element& a, const Element& b);
01512 
01513       /// \brief  The operator overload for multiplying an element and a complex.
01514       friend const std::complex<double> operator* (const Element& a, const std::complex<double>& b);
01515 
01516       /// \brief  The operator overload for multiplying a double and an element.
01517       friend const std::complex<double> operator* (double scalar, const Element& m);
01518       
01519       /// \brief  The operator overload for multiplying a complex and an element.
01520       friend const std::complex<double> operator* (const std::complex<double>& b, const Element& a);
01521 
01522 
01523       /// \brief  The operator overload for dividing an element by a double.
01524       friend const std::complex<double> operator/ (const Element& m, double scalar);
01525 
01526       /// \brief  The operator overload for dividing an element by an element.
01527       friend const std::complex<double> operator/ (const Element& a, const Element& b);
01528 
01529       /// \brief  The operator overload for dividing an element by an complex.
01530       friend const std::complex<double> operator/ (const Element& a, const std::complex<double>& b);
01531 
01532       /// \brief  The operator overload for dividing a double by an element.
01533       friend const std::complex<double> operator/ (double scalar, const Element& m);
01534 
01535       /// \brief  The operator overload for dividing a complex by an element.
01536       friend const std::complex<double> operator/ (const std::complex<double>& b, const Element& a);
01537 
01538 
01539       /// \brief  The operator overload for testing equality between an element and a double.
01540       friend const bool operator== (const Element& m, double scalar);
01541       
01542       /// \brief  The operator overload for testing equality between an element and an element.
01543       friend const bool operator== (const Element& a, const Element& b);
01544 
01545       /// \brief  The operator overload for testing equality between an element and a complex.
01546       friend const bool operator== (const Element& a, const std::complex<double>& b);
01547 
01548       /// \brief  The operator overload for testing equality between a double and an element.
01549       friend const bool operator== (double scalar, const Element& m);
01550       
01551       /// \brief  The operator overload for testing equality between a complex and an element.
01552       friend const bool operator== (const std::complex<double>& b, const Element& a);
01553 
01554     };

01557   public: // Operator Overloads      
01558 
01559     /// \brief  Get a reference to an element in the matrix to set or get its value.
01560     Element& operator() (unsigned row, unsigned col);
01561 
01562     /// \brief  Get a reference to an element in the matrix as a column or row vector to set or get its value.
01563     /// This can be used to access a matrix of (col,row), col = index/nrows, row = index/ncols. 
01564     /// Matrix A(10); // The matrix is real with dimensions 10x1
01565     /// A(0) = 10.0;  // The matrix is real.
01566     /// stComplex cplx = {1.0,2.0};
01567     /// A(1) = cplx;  // The matrix is now complex with dimensions 10x1.
01568     Element& operator() (unsigned index);
01569 
01570 
01571     bool operator+= (const int    scalar) { return (*this)+=(double)scalar; } //!< add a scaler int     (shorthand notation: A += 5).
01572     bool operator+= (const float  scalar) { return (*this)+=(double)scalar; } //!< add a scaler float   (shorthand notation: A += 5).
01573     bool operator+= (const double scalar);                                    //!< add a scaler double  (shorthand notation: A += 5).
01574     bool operator+= (const std::complex<double> cplx);                        //!< add a scaler complex (shorthand notation: A += (5+2i)).
01575 
01576     bool operator-= (const int    scalar) { return (*this)-=(double)scalar; } //!< subtract a scaler int     (shorthand notation: A -= 5).
01577     bool operator-= (const float  scalar) { return (*this)-=(double)scalar; } //!< subtract a scaler float   (shorthand notation: A -= 5).
01578     bool operator-= (const double scalar);                                    //!< subtract a scaler double  (shorthand notation: A -= 5).
01579     bool operator-= (const std::complex<double> cplx);                        //!< subtract a scaler complex (shorthand notation: A -= (5+2i)).
01580 
01581     bool operator*= (const int    scalar) { return (*this)*=(double)scalar; } //!< multiply a scalar int     (shorthand notation: A *= 5).
01582     bool operator*= (const float  scalar) { return (*this)*=(double)scalar; } //!< multiply a scalar float   (shorthand notation: A *= 5).
01583     bool operator*= (const double scalar);                                    //!< multiply a scalar double  (shorthand notation: A *= 5).
01584     bool operator*= (const std::complex<double> cplx);                        //!< multiply a scaler complex (shorthand notation: A *= (5+2i)).
01585 
01586     bool operator/= (const int    scalar) { return (*this)/=(double)scalar; } //!< divide a scalar int     (shorthand notation: A /= 5).
01587     bool operator/= (const float  scalar) { return (*this)/=(double)scalar; } //!< divide a scalar float   (shorthand notation: A /= 5).
01588     bool operator/= (const double scalar);                                    //!< divide a scalar double  (shorthand notation: A /= 5).
01589     bool operator/= (const std::complex<double> cplx);                        //!< divide a scaler complex (shorthand notation: A /= (5+2i)).
01590 
01591     bool operator+= (const Matrix& mat);  //!< add a matrix      (shorthand notation: A += B).   
01592     bool operator-= (const Matrix& mat);  //!< subtract a matrix (shorthand notation: A -= B).
01593 
01594     /// \brief  The postfix ++ operator overload.
01595     /// Add +1.0 to all elements and returns matrix values after the increment, e.g. Matrix B = A++.
01596     /// Use Inplace_Increment for a boolean return for safer operation.
01597     friend Matrix operator++ (Matrix& mat, int);
01598 
01599     /// \brief  The postfix -- operator overload.
01600     /// Subtract 1.0 to all elements and returns matrix values after the increment, e.g. Matrix B = A--.
01601     /// Use Inplace_Decrement for a boolean return for safer operation.  
01602     friend Matrix operator-- (Matrix& mat, int);
01603 
01604     /// \brief  Multiply two matrices and copy the result. Result = mat1 * mat2.
01605     friend Matrix operator* (const Matrix& mat1, const Matrix& mat2); 
01606 
01607     /// \brief  Multiply two matrices and copy the result. Result = mat1 * mat2.
01608     friend Matrix operator* (Matrix& mat1, Matrix& mat2); 
01609 
01610     /// \brief  Add two matrices and copy the result. Result = mat1 + mat2.
01611     friend Matrix operator+ (Matrix& mat1, Matrix& mat2);
01612     
01613     /// \brief  Add two matrices and copy the result. Result = mat1 + mat2.
01614     friend Matrix operator+ (const Matrix& mat1, const Matrix& mat2);
01615 
01616     /// \brief  Subtract two matrices and copy the result. Result = mat1 - mat2.
01617     friend Matrix operator- (Matrix& mat1, Matrix& mat2); 
01618     
01619     /// \brief  Subtract two matrices and copy the result. Result = mat1 - mat2.
01620     friend Matrix operator- (const Matrix& mat1, const Matrix& mat2); 
01621 
01622 
01623     /// \brief  Raise all matrix elements to the power scalar.
01624     friend Matrix operator^ (Matrix& mat, const int scalar)     { return mat^( (double)scalar ); }
01625 
01626     /// \brief  Raise all matrix elements to the power scalar.
01627     friend Matrix operator^ (Matrix& mat, const float scalar)   { return mat^( (double)scalar ); }
01628 
01629     /// \brief  Raise all matrix elements to the power scalar.
01630     friend Matrix operator^ (Matrix& mat, const double scalar);
01631 
01632     /// \brief  Add to a matrix by a scalar variable: ie. A = 2.0 + B and B + 2.0 (adds to 2.0 to all elements).
01633     friend Matrix operator+ (const double scalar, Matrix& mat);
01634     friend Matrix operator+ (Matrix& mat, const int    scalar)  { return ((double)scalar) + mat; }
01635     friend Matrix operator+ (Matrix& mat, const float  scalar)  { return ((double)scalar) + mat; }
01636     friend Matrix operator+ (Matrix& mat, const double scalar)  { return scalar + mat;           }
01637     friend Matrix operator+ (const int    scalar, Matrix& mat)  { return ((double)scalar) + mat; }
01638     friend Matrix operator+ (const float  scalar, Matrix& mat)  { return ((double)scalar) + mat; }
01639 
01640     /// \brief  Subtract from a matrix by a scalar variable: ie. A = B - 2.0.
01641     friend Matrix operator- (Matrix& mat, const double scalar)  { return mat + (-1.0*scalar);         }
01642     friend Matrix operator- (Matrix& mat, const int    scalar)  { return mat + (-1.0*(double)scalar); }
01643     friend Matrix operator- (Matrix& mat, const float  scalar)  { return mat + (-1.0*(double)scalar); }
01644 
01645     /// \brief  Subtract a matrix from a scalar variable: ie. A = 2.0 - B == -B + 2.0
01646     friend Matrix operator- (const double scalar, Matrix& mat);
01647     friend Matrix operator- (const int    scalar, Matrix& mat)  { return mat - ((double)scalar); }
01648     friend Matrix operator- (const float  scalar, Matrix& mat)  { return mat - ((double)scalar); }
01649 
01650     /// \brief  Multiply matrix by a scalar variable: A = 2.0 * B and A = B * 2.0.
01651     friend Matrix operator* (const double scalar, Matrix& mat);
01652     friend Matrix operator* (Matrix& mat, const int    scalar)  { return (((double)scalar) * mat); }
01653     friend Matrix operator* (Matrix& mat, const float  scalar)  { return (((double)scalar) * mat); }
01654     friend Matrix operator* (Matrix& mat, const double scalar)  { return (scalar * mat);           }
01655     friend Matrix operator* (const int    scalar, Matrix& mat)  { return (((double)scalar) * mat); }
01656     friend Matrix operator* (const float  scalar, Matrix& mat)  { return (((double)scalar) * mat); }   
01657 
01658     /// \brief  Divide matrix by a scalar variable: A = B / 2.0.
01659     friend Matrix operator/ (Matrix& mat, const double scalar);
01660     friend Matrix operator/ (Matrix& mat, const int    scalar)  { return mat / ((double)scalar); }
01661     friend Matrix operator/ (Matrix& mat, const float  scalar)  { return mat / ((double)scalar); }
01662 
01663     /// \brief  Divide matrix into a scalar variable: A = 2.0 / B. e.g. A = [2.0 2.0; 2.0 2.0] / B, B is 2x2.
01664     friend Matrix operator/ (const double scalar, Matrix& mat);
01665     friend Matrix operator/ (const int    scalar, Matrix& mat)  { return ((double)scalar) / mat; }
01666     friend Matrix operator/ (const float  scalar, Matrix& mat)  { return ((double)scalar) / mat; }
01667 
01668 
01669     // Accessing matrix data as real only:
01670     // The matrix can be accessed using the square bracket operators.
01671     // e.g. Matrix A(2,2); double b = A[0][0]; A[0][1] = 10.0; A[0][1] = -10.0;
01672   public:
01673 
01674     /// \brief  A nested class for access only to the real part of the matrix. 
01675     /// It is used for operator[] access by the Matrix.    
01676     ///
01677     /// Sequential [][] operators can be used to access the matrix. The
01678     /// first overload of [] is at the Matrix level. This returns a copy of 
01679     /// a RealOnlyAccess and the second overload of [] allows access to the 
01680     /// required element from the matrix.
01681     ///
01682     /// For matrices that are always real. This method of accessing each element
01683     /// is the most efficient.
01684     class RealOnlyAccess
01685     {
01686     public:
01687 
01688       /// \brief  Set or get an element value.
01689       double& operator [] (const unsigned col);
01690 
01691       /// \brief  The matrix is a friend class.
01692       friend class Matrix;
01693 
01694       /// \brief  The only constructor.
01695       RealOnlyAccess( MTX& pMatrix, const unsigned row );
01696 
01697       /// \brief  The destructor.
01698       virtual ~RealOnlyAccess();
01699 
01700       /// \brief  The assignment operator from a double for single index operations. 
01701       RealOnlyAccess& operator=(const double value);
01702 
01703       /// \brief  The assignment operator from another RealOnlyAccess object for single index operations.
01704       RealOnlyAccess& operator=(RealOnlyAccess& rhs);
01705 
01706       /// \brief  The assignment operator from a MatrixElement object for single index operations.
01707       RealOnlyAccess& operator=(Element& rhs);
01708 
01709       /// \brief  The casting operator overload for double.
01710       operator const double();
01711       
01712     public: // operator overloads
01713 
01714       bool operator+= (const int    scalar) { return (*this)+=(double)scalar; } //!< add a scaler int     (shorthand notation: A[0] += 5).
01715       bool operator+= (const float  scalar) { return (*this)+=(double)scalar; } //!< add a scaler float   (shorthand notation: A[0] += 5).
01716       bool operator+= (const double scalar);                                    //!< add a scaler double  (shorthand notation: A[0] += 5).
01717 
01718       bool operator-= (const int    scalar) { return (*this)-=(double)scalar; } //!< subtract a scaler int     (shorthand notation: A[0] -= 5).
01719       bool operator-= (const float  scalar) { return (*this)-=(double)scalar; } //!< subtract a scaler float   (shorthand notation: A[0] -= 5).
01720       bool operator-= (const double scalar);                                    //!< subtract a scaler double  (shorthand notation: A[0] -= 5).
01721 
01722       bool operator*= (const int    scalar) { return (*this)*=(double)scalar; } //!< multiply a scalar int     (shorthand notation: A[0] *= 5).
01723       bool operator*= (const float  scalar) { return (*this)*=(double)scalar; } //!< multiply a scalar float   (shorthand notation: A[0] *= 5).
01724       bool operator*= (const double scalar);                                    //!< multiply a scalar double  (shorthand notation: A[0] *= 5).
01725 
01726       bool operator/= (const int    scalar) { return (*this)/=(double)scalar; } //!< divide a scalar int     (shorthand notation: A[0] /= 5).
01727       bool operator/= (const float  scalar) { return (*this)/=(double)scalar; } //!< divide a scalar float   (shorthand notation: A[0] /= 5).
01728       bool operator/= (const double scalar);                                    //!< divide a scalar double  (shorthand notation: A[0] /= 5).
01729       
01730     private:
01731       /// \brief  Check the specified indices. Throw an exception if they are invalid.
01732       /// \return true if valid, false otherwise. 
01733       bool IndexCheck( const unsigned row, const unsigned col );
01734 
01735       /// \brief  Check the specified index into the Matrix as a vector. 
01736       ///         Throw an exception if the index is invalid.
01737       /// \return true if valid, false otherwise. 
01738       bool IndexCheck( const unsigned index );
01739 
01740       MTX& m_Matrix;   //!< The reference to the source matrix.    
01741       unsigned m_row;  //!< The current row to access.
01742     };
01743 
01744     /// \brief  Retrieve a copy of a RealOnlyAccess object which is then used for the second [] overload.
01745     RealOnlyAccess operator[] (const unsigned row); 
01746 
01747   public: // functions for error handling.
01748 
01749     /// \brief  Clear the matrix from memory and handle the error message.
01750     void MatrixError( const char* error );
01751 
01752     /// \brief  Clear the matrix from memory and handle the error message.
01753     void MatrixError( const char* function, const char* error );
01754 
01755     /// \brief  A static function to handle the error message.
01756     static void StaticMatrixError( const char* error );
01757 
01758     /// \brief  A static function to handle the error message.
01759     static void StaticMatrixError( const char* function, const char* error );
01760 
01761 
01762   protected:
01763 
01764     /// \brief  Check the specified indices. Throw an exception if they are invalid.
01765     /// \return true if valid, false otherwise. return code should not be reached!
01766     bool IndexCheck( const unsigned row, const unsigned col );
01767 
01768     /// \brief  Check the specified index into the Matrix as a vector. 
01769     ///         Throw an exception if the index is invalid.
01770     /// \return true if valid, false otherwise. return code should not be reached!    
01771     bool IndexCheck( const unsigned index );
01772 
01773     /// \brief  A single element from the matrix. This is used for write access with operator().
01774     Element m_MatrixElement;
01775 
01776     /// \brief  The deep level matrix container.
01777     MTX m_Matrix;
01778 
01779     /// \brief  This indicates if the mtx core engine been initialized.
01780     static bool m_IsMTXInitialized; 
01781   };
01782 
01783 } // end namespace Zenautics
